title: Afterpay-bound Michael Saadat gained 'sensitive' information at ASIC
text:
Mr Saadat said he was unable to make any comment when contacted by The Australian Financial Review.

Zip and Afterpay are competitors in a relatively new industry that allows consumers to buy and receive goods and services immediately but pay for their purchase over time.

Mr Saadat will be the director of public policy and regulatory affairs for Afterpay Australia and New Zealand.

As the former chief growth officer of Zip, Mr Mitchell was involved in a 2018 ASIC review of buy now, pay later aimed at identifying potential risks for consumers.

"I was heavily involved in the ASIC review of the eight [buy now, pay later] businesses last year and was part of the four-person team which responded to ASIC at Zip," he told The Financial Review.

"Michael was very, very heavily involved in the review and we spoke to him on a couple of occasions.

"The information ASIC sought was broad, deep and highly commercially sensitive and Michael had access to all of this.

"How Michael will be able to segregate this confidential information in his new role at Afterpay is a mystery to me."

Advertisement

Mr Mitchell has left Zip to set up his own business.

ASIC chairman James Shipton told estimates that he and general counsel Chris Savundra are involved in an inquiry into the "facts and circumstances around this matter".

"We are reviewing engagements internally, we are also looking at expectations expressed by our rules, guidelines and legislation, and we're trying to marry up our internal guidelines and those imposed upon us by legislation with the facts as we know them," Mr Shipton said.

"That process is still under way. We are still in the process of adjudicating and determining and, if I may, I'd like to leave it at that but with an assurance ... that the facts and circumstances have triggered an inquiry and an inquiry is under way.

"We are conducting it in the appropriate manner and it is being handled and coordinated by, amongst others, our general counsel, our people and development team and I am also involved."

Labor senator Jenny McAllister asked Mr Shipton to take three further questions on notice, including whether Mr Saadat had had access to sensitive regulatory information.

"Mr Saadat was involved in high-level decision-making about regulatory policy and I wish to understand the protections that were in place during his employment in relation to his obligations to keep that information confidential," she said.

Senator McAllister also wanted to know about Mr Saadat's access to commercially sensitive information.

Advertisement

"Mr Saadat was helping lay the development of the position on the buy now, pay later sector and there were industry consultations as part of that process," she said.

"I'd like to understand whether Mr Saadat would have been given access to commercially sensitive information about buy now, pay later sector competitors."

The third question was about whether Mr Saadat was engaged in conversations about employment with Afterpay when he previously gave evidence to the Senate committee about the buy now, pay later sector.
description: Mr Saadat previously led an ASIC inquiry into buy now, pay later businesses and gave evidence on behalf of ASIC to the banking royal commission.
